key_points: A 17-year-old male student at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School was arrested for threatening a mass shooting.
The Broward County Sheriff's Office arrested the student after being alerted to the threat around 11 p.m. Wednesday.
The student has been charged with one count of writing threats to carry out a mass shooting.
The arrest follows a recent deadly school shooting in Michigan at Oxford High School, where four students were killed.
Principal Michelle Kefford issued a robocall to parents advising them to discuss the seriousness of making threats.
Concerns arise about potential copycat threats following the Michigan shooting.
Several Detroit area schools closed Thursday due to a rise in threats of violence on social media.
In 2018, there was a mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School that left 17 people dead.
The 2018 shooter, former student Nikolas Cruz, pleaded guilty and prosecutors are seeking the death penalty.
Activist Manuel Oliver, father of a 2018 massacre victim, was in Washington hoping to meet President Biden about gun control.
spokespersons: Michelle Kefford (Principal, Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School)
Manuel Oliver (Activist, Father of 2018 massacre victim)
